predictions.reasoning: PATTERN P-2-1 applies: Contributor comment explicitly states 'the stale gateway reconnection problem has since been addressed through newer changes on `main`, so this specific patch is no longer needed.' This is a terminal non-merge signal indicating the fix landed elsewhere (supersession). First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with no maintainer label, no approval, and explicit supersession language. Author's self-advocacy comment does not override the maintainer/community signal that the work is obsolete.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) adding new AI provider (LM Studio) onboarding. PR lacks: (1) any human reviewer comments or approvals (only automated Greptile review), (2) maintainer engagement or maintainer label, (3) explicit test evidence in PR description. PATTERN P-3-6 applies: 'New AI provider addition PRs from first-time contributors without tests, maintainer engagement, or approval rarely merge.' Small scope (5 files) and focused feature do not overcome the absence of human review and maintainer approval for a first-time contributor.

PATTERN P-3-1 applies: Author comment explicitly states 'I originally filed issue #7768 and submitted this PR as my proposed fix. @sebslight closed #7768 as a [duplicate/resolved], so this PR is now orphaned.' This is a terminal non-merge signal indicating the issue was closed/resolved elsewhere and the PR is orphaned. Author (0% merge rate across 2 prior PRs) self-identifies the PR as superseded. The security-focused nature of the fix (DNS rebinding prevention) does not override the explicit supersession.

PATTERN P-2-2 applies: Member comment from steipete explicitly states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with merge commit hash ($merge_sha). This is a terminal positive merge signal. The author tyler6204 has a 100% merge rate across 4 prior PRs, holds a maintainer label, and addresses a major infrastructure overhaul (cron delivery model migration). The PR is XL-sized (68 files) with multiple labels (docs, app: macos, app: web-ui, gateway, cli, agents, maintainer), but the commit-hash-backed merge receipt overrides all other considerations per the learned patterns. The merge receipt is the terminal authoritative signal.

PATTERN P-6-3 applies: Member comment from sebslight states 'Closing as duplicate of #...' (implied by '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' which is the standard duplicate closure template per P-6-3). Author vishaltandale00 has a 0% merge rate across 10 prior PRs. The PR targets a critical file descriptor leak in bash-tools (agents category), which is technically important, but the explicit member duplicate closure is a terminal non-merge signal that overrides technical merit. PATTERN P-1-11 reinforces: 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs (10) combined with no human reviewer engagement (only automated review) makes merge unlikely. The duplicate closure comment is definitive.

PATTERN P-2-1 applies: Contributor comment explicitly states 'Closed by #14257 — replaced with a unified process supervisor that handles PTY and child process teardown.' This is a terminal non-merge signal indicating the fix was superseded and replaced by a more comprehensive PR (#14257). The author gavinbmoore has a 33.3% merge rate (2/6 prior PRs) and modest engagement, but the explicit supersession language takes precedence. This is a focused one-file fix, but the supersession comment is definitive.

PATTERN P-2-2 applies: Member/contributor comment from vignesh07 (the author, a CONTRIBUTOR with maintainer label) explicitly states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main. Land commit: - Merge commit:' indicating a merge receipt. The author vignesh07 has a strong 100% merge rate across 8 prior PRs and holds a maintainer label. The PR addresses legacy config migration (config category), a critical infrastructure task affecting docs, macos, web-ui, gateway, cli, and agents. The merge receipt language with 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' and reference to Land/Merge commits is a terminal positive merge signal per P-2-2. Medium-large scope (6 files, L-sized) with maintainer label and merge receipt confirms merge prediction.

Author 0xRaini explicitly closes the PR with comment 'Closing — deprioritizing older PRs to reduce review burden.' PATTERN P-1-8 applies: Author self-reports maintenance activity (deprioritization/closure) without maintainer engagement, signaling a stalled PR unlikely to merge. The author has a low merge rate (1/22 = 4.5%) and, despite the PR addressing a genuine bug (sessions_list showing wrong model) with a full test suite and self-advocacy, the author's own decision to close overrides other positive signals. The lack of human reviewer engagement (only automated Greptile review, no MEMBER/maintainer comments) combined with the author's explicit closure and low historical merge rate confirms the prediction.

Author 0xRaini explicitly closes the PR with comment 'Closing in favor of #14152 which has the same fix with a cleaner branch.' PATTERN P-3-1 applies: Author comment explicitly states the PR is superseded by another PR (#14152). This is a terminal non-merge signal. Despite the PR addressing a legitimate Node.js v23 compatibility issue (tiny 4-line fix) with the author's moderate engagement, the author's own supersession statement takes precedence. The author's 15.5% merge rate (9/58 prior PRs) and focused scope do not override the explicit closure. The mention of a 'cleaner branch' in the successor PR (#14152) confirms this is an intentional consolidation rather than a rejection of the fix.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) submitting a one-line fix for a Windows-specific spawn EINVAL error in ui.js. PR is XS-sized and focused on a narrow bug, but lacks: (1) any human reviewer comments or approvals (only automated review would be present if any), (2) maintainer engagement or maintainer label, (3) test evidence, (4) comment evidence in PR description of CI status or fix validation. PATTERN P-5-5 and P-3-6 apply: First-time contributor with no human reviewer engagement, no maintainer comment, and no visible tests is unlikely to merge despite narrow scope. The 0% merge rate combined with lack of human engagement (no visible comments) and absence of maintainer label makes merge unlikely, though the XS size and focused nature provide some signal.

First-time contributor (0% merge rate across 1 prior PR) with XS/S-sized docs+code PR. Has only automated Greptile review + one community comment addressing concern validity. Zero human reviewer approval or maintainer engagement. Per P-5-7, first-time contributors with only automated reviews and no human reviewer engagement are unlikely to merge. No maintainer label or explicit approval present. The author is pinging for help but no maintainer has responded.

Member comment from sebslight states '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' This matches P-8-2 pattern: 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' is a terminal non-merge signal. The comment text is truncated but the period followed by conditional reopen language indicates a closure decision. First-time contributor (0% merge rate) with no prior PRs. Despite production validation from adasowa and author request for review, the member closure comment is terminal. Per P-6-2, member duplicate/closure comments override technical merit and positive community validation.

First-time contributor (0% merge rate) with XS-sized PR. steipete (CONTRIBUTOR, not MEMBER) comment states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' but is truncated and appears to list failing tests (src/auto-reply/command-control.test.ts, src/agents/pi-tools.safe-bins.test.ts, etc.). This is NOT a merge receipt with commit hash; it describes a rebase attempt with concurrent test failures. Per P-5-7, first-time contributors with no human reviewer approval and failing/unclear CI status are unlikely to merge. The steipete comment shows CI problems, not a successful merge signal. kelvinCB is requesting admin help with stuck macOS jobs, indicating unresolved CI issues.

Author self-declared closure: '1kuna' comment states 'This has been resubmitted from my main account. Please see the replacement PR linked above. This PR can be closed.' Followed by '1alyx' (original author) confirming 'Closing - migrated to 1kuna account. Same fixes resubmitted from verified account.' This is an explicit author supersession statement per P-1-2: author explicitly states the PR is superseded by another PR (resubmitted under different account). Terminal non-merge signal. Author has 0% merge rate across 3 prior PRs, reinforcing the non-merge prediction.

Member comment from grp06 begins with 'Closing:' (truncated), indicating closure. Community comment from matthewpapa07 states 'found a different fix here https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/9393' — pointing to PR #9393 as the preferred solution. First-time contributor (0% merge rate) with XS-sized PR. Member closure comment is terminal per P-6-2. The truncation suggests likely duplicate closure language. Even without full text visible, the 'Closing:' language combined with matthewpapa07's pointer to an alternative PR (#9393) and member involvement indicates non-merge.

First-time contributor (0% merge rate across 1 prior PR) with XS/S-sized PR targeting cron fix. Despite high community engagement (6 comments, 4 unique users reporting critical impact, production interest), there is zero human reviewer approval and no maintainer label. matthewpapa07 identifies three related PRs (#9573, #9393, current) attempting similar fixes, indicating confusion and lack of coordination. The comment 'all 3 fixes are pretty different. Gotta love vibe coding lol' suggests maintainer skepticism about the approach. Per P-5-9, first-time contributors with high comment engagement but no human reviewer approval have low merge probability. No maintainer engagement or approval present; only community validation is insufficient per P-6-1.

Member comment from sebslight: 'Closing as duplicate/, which is the canonical PR for the Bash 3.2 compatibility fix in docker-setup.sh.' This is an explicit duplicate closure per P-6-2 and P-8-2. Terminal non-merge signal. Despite author having 20% merge rate (1 of 5 prior PRs merged), extensive self-maintenance activity (rebasing, CI retriggers, addressing Greptile concerns), test additions, and positive community comments from zackdotcomputer ('seems to fix the error'), the member duplicate closure is terminal. Per P-1-9, member explicit duplicate closure overrides all positive indicators including technical merit, author prior merge rate, and community validation. The duplicate closure is the authoritative terminal signal.

Author succ985 has 100% merge rate (1 of 1 prior PR merged). M-sized PR targeting agents category with maintainer-relevant fix (provider configuration respect in compaction/session-memory). No explicit closure or non-merge signals present. Greptile automated review provided (2 comments). However, no human reviewer approval, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment, zero community comments. Per P-5-6, even with 100% prior merge rate, requiring human reviewer engagement when rate based on limited prior PRs (just 1). But the 100% rate + targeted feature fix + absence of negative signals suggest moderate merge likelihood. The lack of any engagement or approval is concerning but not disqualifying given the strong prior history. Confidence held to 0.71 due to absence of any explicit approval or maintainer engagement.

Author Hua688 self-declares closure: 'Closing this PR because it included unrelated non-Signal commits. (signal-only diff).' This is explicit author self-closure due to scope/content issues. XL-sized PR (27 files) from first-time contributor (0% merge rate) with multiple unrelated component changes (extensions/memory-lancedb, docker, scripts, docs, package management files alongside Signal channel work). Per AGENTS.md guidance on cross-cutting refactors: 'consider all built-in + extension channels when refactoring shared logic'. The PR's multi-component nature and author's acknowledgment of unrelated commits indicates scope creep and lack of discipline. Per P-1-2, author explicit closure is terminal. The XL size and first-time contributor status would make this unlikely to merge anyway, but the author's own admission of mixed concerns is definitive.

Author steipete has MEMBER association, 100% merge rate (11 of 11 prior PRs merged), and maintainer label. M-sized PR targeting Slack media normalization. No closure signals, no supersession comments. Cursor automated review raised 'Medium Risk' concern about concurrency/edge-cases in Slack downloads but no explicit non-approval. For high-reputation members with maintainer labels, the 100% merge rate and explicit maintainer label are strong positive signals. The Cursor comment is qualitative concern, not a block. Per learned patterns, maintainer-labeled PRs have 90.7% merge rate. steipete's strong history + maintainer label + M-size + lack of closure signals support merge prediction. Cursor's reported issue is informational but not deterministic blocking.

PR #6372 is explicitly flagged as a duplicate of PR #7458 by a CONTRIBUTOR comment ('PR #7458 appears to implement the same fix'). Member sebslight's comment with 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' is a duplicate closure notice (P-6-3). First-time contributor status, zero human reviewer engagement (only automated greptile review), and member duplicate triage all converge on closure. Terminal non-merge signal per P-5-1 and P-6-2.

PR #6505 addresses the same WhatsApp filename bug as PR #6372 (both fix the hardcoded 'file' issue). Glucksberg's comment references the same underlying issue #10862. Member sebslight's comment with duplicate closure phrasing is a terminal non-merge signal. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs), no maintainer label, only automated greptile review. The duplication and member triage closure statement indicate this PR will not merge independently. Terminal closure signal per P-6-2 and P-6-3.

Author hclsys explicitly closes the PR with comment 'Closing: no linked issue and no review engagement after 7 days.' This is an author-initiated closure. While hclsys has 15 prior PRs (only 1 merged, 6.7% merge rate), the explicit author self-closure statement is terminal. XS scope and automated greptile review only, no human engagement. Author's own decision to close overrides any other signals per P-1-11 (author closure language).

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). PR labeled as gateway feature (skipDevicePairingForTrustedProxy option). No human reviewer approval or comments—only automated greptile review. Member sebslight comment contains triage language 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' suggesting duplicate/low-priority closure. No maintainer label, no human engagement. Matches P-6-1 (first-time contributor with only automated reviews and no maintainer approval). Terminal closure signal.

Author openperf explicitly closes the PR: 'Closing this PR — the underlying bug has been [fixed], which introduced SessionManager.appendMessage() to automatically maintain the parentId chain. My manual readTranscriptLeafId approach is no longer needed.' This is an author statement that the PR is superseded by another merged PR/commit (P-1-2 supersession). First-time author (1 prior PR, 0% merge rate), XS size, but the explicit author supersession comment is terminal. Author's own closure statement overrides all other signals.

PR title 'Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/ci-tiered-gates-v2'' indicates an accidental or incorrect merge of an entire branch rather than a feature branch. This is a merge-branch-HEAD operation, not a feature PR. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs). Only automated greptile review, no human engagement. No tests evident (docs + agents labels). The PR structure itself (merging a remote branch) is anomalous and indicates accidental PR creation or fork merge issue per P-0-1 patterns. Terminal closure signal.

First-time author (1 prior PR, 0% merge rate) but has received APPROVED review status from Takhoffman (CONTRIBUTOR) who: (1) initially requested changes citing blocker ('/clear does not exist'), (2) fixed the issues themselves via rebase and commit, and (3) issued APPROVED status twice. The PR includes tests and fixes a straightforward error message bug. While the author has 0% prior merge rate, the engaged reviewer with explicit APPROVED status (P-1-3 override) and author responsiveness to feedback demonstrates human engagement. No maintainer label, but the APPROVED review from an engaged domain expert (Takhoffman rebased and fixed the PR directly) is a strong positive signal. Size is XS (3 files). Confidence tempered by first-time contributor status and prior 0% rate, but APPROVED + engaged reviewer pushes toward merge.

PR has 0 files changed (P-1-15 terminal signal: 'PRs with zero files changed (0 files in diff) are not merged regardless of label, size designation, or feature description'). This is a structural impossibility—a PR cannot be merged if it modifies no files. Author Cynosure159 has 2 prior PRs with 0% merge rate. Terminal non-merge signal regardless of any other factors.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS docs-only PR fixing Mermaid dark mode rendering. PR includes 5 files (CHANGELOG, docs). No comments visible in the PR (all silence—no maintainer engagement, no human reviewer comments, no approval). Only automated greptile review is absent from visible comments. Per P-5-6: 'XS-sized doc-only PRs with CI green, focused scope, and an author with 100% prior merge rate on at least 1 prior PR are predicted as merge, but absent any human reviewer comment or approval they frequently do not merge.' Author has 0% prior merge rate (not 100%), and there is zero human reviewer engagement. This is a low-engagement first-time contributor docs PR with no maintainer participation—terminal closure signal.

Terminal non-merge signal: steipete (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly states 'We accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back for now' with revert commit SHAs mentioned. This matches P-5-4: 'A contributor comment stating 'We accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back' with explicit revert commit SHAs is a terminal non-merge signal, equivalent to P-5-3, even when the original merge SHAs are present.' The PR was merged but then reverted. Despite author rodrigouroz having strong history (10 prior PRs, 60% merge rate) and trusted-contributor label, the explicit revert instruction is terminal. Steipete's follow-up 'Please re-open this in a new PR, needs far more time to review' confirms the PR will not merge in its current form. XL size (14 files) compounds the complexity and review burden. Terminal closure/revert signal per P-5-4.

Member comment from sebslight contains 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' — this is phrasing consistent with P-6-3 (explicit duplicate closure with reopen clause). Combined with greptile-apps identifying a P0 issue in the workflow logic (digest/imagetools mismatch), this PR is being closed as flawed. First-time contributor, 0% merge rate, no maintainer label, and the member's language signals closure not merge.

Member sebslight comment with 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' — phrasing consistent with P-6-3 (explicit duplicate/closure language). Addresses same issue as PR #4577 (ARM64 Docker image tagging). First-time contributor, 0% merge rate, no maintainer label, no human reviewer engagement, no tests. Terminal non-merge signal per P-6-3.

Member sebslight comment with 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' — phrasing consistent with P-6-3 (closure language). First-time contributor, 0% merge rate, no maintainer label, no human reviewer engagement, no tests, single file change. No evidence of technical merit or review. Terminal non-merge signal per P-6-3.

New AI provider (Lark/Feishu channel) from first-time contributor with 0% merge rate. While PR has tests (api.test.ts present) and greptile review, there is NO maintainer label, NO maintainer comment, NO human approval. Per P-0-6 pattern: 'New AI provider addition PRs from first-time contributors without tests, maintainer engagement, or approval rarely merge.' Tests are present but maintainer engagement and approval are absent. Combined with 11 files touched (medium-large scope for first-timer), this falls into high-risk category. Greptile review is automated, not human engagement.

Author alfadb has 0% merge rate across 2 prior PRs. Per P-2-4: 'Authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs who receive a trusted-contributor bulk-landing merge comment with a commit hash are merged, overriding the negative author history signal.' However, this PR has NO merge receipt comment, NO maintainer label, NO maintainer comment. Only automated reviews (copilot-pull-request-reviewer, greptile-apps). Per P-1-11 and P-2-4: repeated bot pings without human engagement + 0% merge rate = very unlikely merge. Focused scope (2 files, cli feature) and labels (slack, cli) are positive but insufficient without human approval or maintainer engagement.

Member comment from gumadeiras explicitly states 'we are already on 0.52.5; stale' — indicating the PR is obsolete and unnecessary. Terminal non-merge signal. First-time contributor, 0% merge rate, no maintainer label. The PR proposes a dependency bump that has already been completed. Clear closure justification.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) but PR is small (3 files, XS-sized), focused feature (Telegram spoiler tag support). Includes tests (format.test.ts), has changelog entry, touches only telegram channel (not multi-channel). NO maintainer label, NO human reviewer comments/approvals, only automated reviews absent. However, the narrow scope (XS), presence of tests, changelog documentation, and focused single-channel touch suggest this may pass community triage. Confidence is moderate due to absence of human approval — per P-5-7 'XS-sized doc-only PRs...frequently do not merge [without human reviewer comment]' — but this includes tests + code, not docs-only. Small first-time contributor PRs with tests sometimes merge via triage acceptance even without explicit approval.

Author alfadb has 0% merge rate across 10 prior PRs — extreme negative signal per P-1-11 and P-2-4. PR includes automated reviews (copilot, chatgpt-codex-connector) but NO human reviewer approval, NO maintainer label, NO maintainer comment, NO merge receipt comment. Per P-2-4: 'Authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs...are very unlikely to merge even when the PR includes tests and addresses a documented issue [without commit-hash-backed merge receipt].' The PR addresses a legitimate issue (context overflow circuit breaker), has 6 files touched and technical depth, but the absence of human engagement combined with 0% historical merge rate across 10 prior PRs is a terminal negative signal. No exception applies without merge receipt or maintainer engagement.

Author comment from BinHPdev (CONTRIBUTOR role) explicitly states 'Closing: consolidating open PRs to focus on higher-impact fixes.' This is an explicit author supersession/closure statement per P-3-2: 'An author comment explicitly stating the PR is superseded by a specific PR number is a terminal non-merge signal, even when a reviewer has approved.' While this PR doesn't cite a specific superseding PR number, the author's direct statement that they are 'closing' the PR to consolidate efforts is a terminal signal equivalent to supersession. Combined with 50 prior PRs and only 3 merged (6% merge rate), author is explicitly choosing to abandon this PR. Terminal non-merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS-S sized PR (2 files, feishu channel). Focused fix (mention detection for post messages with embedded docs). Includes tests (bot.checkBotMentioned.test.ts modified). Has channel label (feishu) and size label (S). Greptile review present. NO maintainer label, NO maintainer comment, NO human approval comments. Per P-5-6 and P-5-7: 'S-sized PRs from authors with 100% merge rate based on a single prior PR but with failing CI and no human reviewer comments or approvals do not reliably merge.' This PR has 0% rate (worse than 100%), but size is small (S) and no failing CI mentioned. The narrow scope (single channel, 2 files), presence of tests, and S-label size suggest moderate merge probability. However, absence of human approval + 0% author history limits confidence. Moderate prediction reflecting uncertainty.

First-time contributor (0/8 prior PRs merged, 0% merge rate) adding new provider (LM Studio onboarding). XS-sized PR (5 files) but category is 'commands' (provider addition). No human reviewer engagement—only automated greptile review. No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no tests visible in diff. Pattern P-2-7 applies: new provider addition from first-time contributor with no human reviewer engagement, no maintainer label, and no evidence of tests. Terminal non-merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with focused critical fix (watcher limit fallback, agents category). Small scope (5 files, all tests + implementation). CI appears green (test files present). However, no human reviewer engagement—only automated bot comment from 'clawdinator' (CONTRIBUTOR role, triage bot, not a human reviewer). No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no approval. Pattern P-2-6 applies: first-time contributor with high comment engagement (author + bot) but zero human reviewer approval. Pattern P-1-11 applies: author without maintainer engagement or label, bot pings are compensatory self-advocacy without human engagement. Terminal non-merge signal.

PR explicitly closed by author with comment 'Closing per request; reopening as a fresh PR without legacy asteriskAri.format.' This is a terminal non-merge signal—the work was superseded/reframed into a fresh PR (likely #10581). Author has 0% merge rate across 3 prior PRs. Pattern P-3-1 applies: author comment explicitly stating PR is superseded indicates non-merge. The fresh reopening is evidence of intentional closure, not accidental draft state.

Fresh PR from w0s1nsk1 (reopen after #10535 closure). Author has 0% merge rate across 5 prior PRs, making this a low-merge-author pattern. Adding new asterisk-ari voice-call provider (9 files, extension/channel work). No human reviewer approvals—only automated bot reviews (greptile, codex-connector). No maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Author self-comment describes env var handling but no approval follows. Pattern P-2-7 applies: new provider/extension addition from first-time/low-merge contributor with no human approval and no maintainer engagement. Pattern P-1-11 applies: 0% merge rate + zero human reviewer engagement + repeated automated bot comments. Terminal non-merge signal.

Author 0xRaini closed the PR themselves with final comment 'Closing — focusing on higher-impact PRs' (appears twice, second is duplicate close). This is an explicit author closure signal, equivalent to non-merge. Critical stability fix for gateway (2 files, small scope, tests present) but author deprioritized it. Author has only 1/21 merged (4.8% rate), and despite pinging @Takhoffman twice for review with justification ('Critical stability fix', 'subtle infinite restart loop'), no human review was received and author self-closed. Pattern P-3-1 applies: author explicitly closing PR indicates non-merge decision by author. Terminal signal.

Maintainer comment from Takhoffman (CONTRIBUTOR role) explicitly states: '() during bulk landing. Closing this PR to keep a single landing path.' This indicates the fix was already merged via bulk landing into another PR/branch, making this PR redundant/superseded. Pattern P-2-1 applies: maintainer/contributor comment stating 'Fixed in [context]' or 'during bulk landing' is terminal non-merge signal. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with single-file fix; despite having an approval from Saran789159, the bulk-landing supersession is terminal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) adding chrome-relay resilience features (3 files, M-sized). Author claims improvements adopted from parallel PR #15817 and self-documents two commits of changes. However, no human reviewer approval—only automated greptile comment. No maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Author self-advocacy comments about incorporating #15817 improvements, but this is self-documentation without human review. Pattern P-2-6 applies: first-time contributor with high self-engagement but zero human reviewer approval. No maintainer engagement signal. Likely closed as superseded by #15817 (the 'best-of-breed' original PR) or awaiting explicit maintainer decision not evident in thread.

Author christianklotz has 100% merge rate (10/10 prior PRs merged). PR has maintainer label (very strong signal: 90.7% merge rate per feature spec). M-sized PR (6 files) in agents category with CHANGELOG update, tests, and implementation. No explicit closure or objection comments. All positive indicators: established author with perfect track record, maintainer label present, reasonable scope, tests present. Pattern P-5-6 does not apply (this is not a single-prior-PR case or failing CI scenario). This is a high-confidence merge prediction.

Author alinaqi explicitly closed PR with comment: 'Closing: PR should target alinaqi/openclaw fork instead'. This is a terminal non-merge signal—author indicates the PR was submitted to the wrong repository/branch. XL-sized PR (9 files, agents category, Google Calendar tools) with 0% merge rate across 3 prior PRs. Author explicitly closing due to submission error. Pattern P-3-1 applies: author's own statement that PR should not be merged in this location. Even though automated greptile review is present, the explicit closure by author for procedural/scope reasons is terminal.

Author aldoeliacim has 33.3% merge rate (2/6 prior PRs merged), which is above baseline (~24%). S-sized PR (2 files, web-ui category) with focused fix for webchat rendering issue #18079. Two automated reviewer comments present (copilot, greptile). No explicit rejection or closure. Author is experienced enough (6 prior PRs) with reasonable merge history. Pattern P-5-8 concern: author has merge rate from fewer than 3 unmerged PRs in positive direction (2 merged out of 6 total). Scope is narrow and technically sound (message text extraction fix). No maintainer label but no maintainer objection either. Moderate confidence merge due to author track record above baseline and focused scope, despite lack of human reviewer approval.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with L-sized PR. Despite having tests and a detailed CLAWDINATOR review identifying a fixable bug ('--keep-config help text is inverted'), the pattern shows first-time contributors with XS/S-sized PRs with only automated reviews and no human reviewer approval rarely merge (P-5-8). The author's repeated self-pings to greptile bot without any human reviewer engagement compounds the non-merge signal (P-1-11, P-2-4). CLAWDINATOR's code review is helpful but is automated; no maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no human approval present.

Author with 4 prior PRs and 0% merge rate (P-1-11). The comment 'which covers the same fix (and also includes video files)' indicates the author themselves is suggesting the PR is superseded by another fix that has broader scope. This matches P-3-1 (author comment stating PR is superseded). Combined with 0% merge rate across 4 prior PRs and no human reviewer engagement (zero comments from humans, only automated review), this is a terminal non-merge signal. XS-sized scope does not overcome the 0% merge rate + supersession signal.

Medium-sized PR from author with 28.6% merge rate (4/14 prior merged), experienced-contributor label, and agents category. Takhoffman's comment 'This was a good idea. I expanded it...' and 'Appreciate the PR!' signals positive maintainer/senior contributor engagement. The PR has tests, moderate scope (6 files, M-sized), and addresses logging diagnostics with explicit code context matching existing patterns. Experienced-contributor label is a moderate positive signal. However, no formal APPROVED review state visible and no explicit merge receipt. The 28.6% rate is solid but below 50%, so requires the maintainer engagement signal which is present via Takhoffman's enthusiastic endorsement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with terminal positive signal: member comment 'Landed via local gate + squash merge into main. Gate: pnpm build && pnpm check && pnpm test' with merge commit present. This is a commit-hash-backed merge receipt from a MEMBER (grp06), which per P-2-2 and P-4-2 is a terminal positive merge signal that overrides all other signals including first-time contributor status, 0% merge rate, and absence of maintainer label. The PR touches 16 files across security/gateway/cli/commands/agents (broad scope but justified by comprehensive security scanner feature), has tests, and received substantive Greptile feedback which the author addressed.

Author with 7 prior PRs and 0% merge rate. Large-scope PR (16 files, L-sized) touching extensions and core functionality. Per P-1-11, authors with 0% merge rate across 2+ prior PRs with no human reviewer engagement (zero human comments, only automated reviews from greptile and chatgpt-codex-connector bots) are very unlikely to merge. The PR has no maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no human approval. Automated bot reviews do not constitute human engagement. XL-sized extension work from 0% merge rate author without maintainer oversight fails the merge bar even if technically sound.

Author with 8 prior PRs and 0% merge rate (w0s1nsk1 — one more PR than #12485, same pattern). XL-sized PR (18 files) with high complexity (asterisk ARI provider + core STT for voice-call extension). Per P-1-11, 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs with zero human reviewer engagement is a terminal non-merge signal. Only automated bot reviews present (greptile, chatgpt-codex-connector). No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no human approval. Large scope + 0% merge history + extensions + zero human engagement = non-merge. Similar to #12485 but with even more files and one additional prior unmerged PR.

Author VintLin with 22 prior PRs and 0% merge rate (worst in batch by prior count). Critical signal: author's own comment states 'Superseded by a cleaner, atomic reconstruction with updated identity information.' This is an explicit author supersession declaration per P-3-1, which is a terminal non-merge signal. Combined with 0% merge rate across 22 prior PRs and only automated greptile review (no human engagement, no maintainer label), the PR cannot merge. Author's own statement that the work landed elsewhere is dispositive.

Terminal non-merge signal: MEMBER comment from thewilloftheshadow states 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue.' This is an explicit member-driven closure with stated reason (author spam/account restriction). Author shtse8 has 53 prior PRs but only 3.8% merge rate (2 merged). The member comment constitutes a definitive non-merge determination. Even though the PR is M-sized with reasonable scope (2 files, web-ui), the member's explicit closure statement overrides all other signals.

Author's explicit closure comment: 'Closing: did not follow proper workflow.' This is a self-initiated closure with stated procedural reason. Despite author lailoo having a solid 30.0% merge rate (9/30 prior merged) and trusted-contributor label, the author's own decision to close the PR is terminal. The PR is XS-sized and narrowly scoped (config schema key support), but the author determined it did not follow proper workflow and closed it. Per patterns P-3-1 and author agency, respect the author's explicit closure statement.

Author arosstale's explicit closure comment: 'Closing — merge conflicts with main, and the area has seen recent changes. Will re-evaluate if still needed.' This is a procedural self-closure citing merge conflicts and area churn. Despite author arosstale having solid credentials (93 prior PRs, 10.8% merge rate, trusted-contributor + experienced-contributor labels), and despite kentaro's supportive comment noting the PR would fix #16041, the author explicitly closed the PR due to conflicts and area instability. Per P-3-1, author explicit closure is terminal. The author's decision to defer reflects good judgment given the conflict state.

Member comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' is procedurally courteous language accompanying a duplicate closure (per P-6-3). First-time contributor with 0% prior merge rate. No maintainer label, no approval, no human reviewer engagement. Terminal non-merge signal.

Strong positive signals: (1) Maintainer label present (90.7% merge rate signal). (2) Author has 100% merge rate across 8 prior PRs. (3) M-sized feature PR with 23 files—within healthy scope. (4) Human reviewer approval from Ari4ka (CONTRIBUTOR). (5) Touches multiple channels and extensions (risky by AGENTS.md guidelines) but maintainer label + strong author history override this. (6) Automated reviews present but not blocking.

Terminal non-merge signal (P-1-2, P-3-1): MEMBER comment explicitly states 'Superseded by #11641' with closure instruction. First-time contributor with 0% merge rate. Supersession by another PR—work absorbed elsewhere. No merge receipt for original PR. Automated review present but overridden by explicit supersession statement.

Terminal positive merge signal (P-2-2, P-4-2): CONTRIBUTOR comment from steipete states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with explicit merge commit reference. First-time contributor with 0% prior merge rate, but commit-hash-backed merge receipt overrides this per learned patterns. Author self-advocacy pings to greptile are present but the merge receipt is the terminal authoritative signal. S-sized feature PR with tests and docs.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated bot (openclaw-barnacle) posted 6 closure comments stating 'Closing this PR because it looks dirty (too many unrelated commits)'. XL-sized PR (1116 files, exceeds 100-file threshold per P-2-3) with multiple unrelated changes across many components. Author has 25% merge rate (1/4 prior PRs). High engagement (37 comments) but repetitive bot closures override positive author history and engagement. Author responses to review feedback are present but bot-triggered closure is terminal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). XS-sized PR (3 files). Only author self-advocacy comment mentioning '@tmchow' (no actual maintainer engagement). One automated review from greptile. No maintainer label, no human reviewer approval, no maintainer comment. Per P-5-11, authors with 0% merge rate who self-ping with minimal human engagement are unlikely to merge. No tests listed. Narrow scope helps slightly, but lack of human engagement and zero prior merge history are terminal signals.

Terminal non-merge signal (P-1-2, P-3-1): MEMBER comment from tyler6204 explicitly states 'Closing this out, superseded by other work in this area.' Supersession by unspecified related work—PR will not be merged independently. Author has 100% prior merge rate (1 prior PR) but supersession comment overrides this. M-sized feature PR with 4 files. Automated review present but overridden by explicit member supersession statement.

Terminal non-merge signal (P-2-1): CONTRIBUTOR comment from vignesh07 explicitly states 'Has been fixed in latest main in response to the linked issue.' This indicates the fix landed on main via a separate path, superseding the original PR per P-2-1 ('Fixed in #NNNN' or 'Fixed on main' phrasing). Author Clawborn has 0% merge rate across 3 prior PRs. S-sized PR but fix is already live on main. Author acknowledges the information. No maintainer label, no approval, no merge receipt for this PR.

Terminal non-merge signal (P-3-1): Author Clawborn explicitly comments 'Closing — overlaps with #8078 which addresses the same class of issue.' Author self-closure with supersession language. XS-sized PR (2 files) but work is covered by #8078. Author has 0% merge rate across 7 prior PRs. No maintainer label, no approval, no human engagement. Author's own supersession statement is a terminal non-merge signal per P-3-1 (author-initiated supersession closure).

Terminal non-merge signal (P-3-1): Author Clawborn explicitly comments 'Closing — overlaps with #8078 which addresses the same class of issue.' Author self-closure with supersession language. XS-sized PR (2 files) addressing proto-pollution in deepMerge, but work covered by #8078. Author has 0% merge rate across 9 prior PRs (highest count in this batch). Persistent 0% merge rate signal compounded by author self-closure. No maintainer label, no approval, no human engagement.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy' per P-1-10. PR has 22 labels and 1536 files changed (far exceeds 100-file threshold). The closure comment is a deterministic automation trigger. Additionally, first comment notes 'rebase completely failed', compounding the non-merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with only a non-maintainer CONTRIBUTOR approval (clawdinator) from greptile-apps. No maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer engagement beyond automated Greptile review. Per P-7-2, CONTRIBUTOR-role approvals are insufficient for first-time contributors without maintainer label or maintainer comment. The vague closing emoji comment from clawdinator does not constitute substantive human engagement.

Terminal non-merge signal: Member (sebslight) comment states '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' which is the exact phrasing pattern from P-6-3 (duplicate closure with reopen clause). Per P-6-3, this is a terminal non-merge signal regardless of technical merit. The Glucksberg comment references issue #9229 but does not override the member's duplicate closure. First-time contributor with 0% merge rate and zero human reviewer approvals compounds the signal.

First-time contributor (author has 1 prior PR, 0 merged = 0% merge rate) with only automated Greptile review comment. Greptile flagged a critical concern: 'MCP capabilities advertised but not actually wired to tool execution' (P2 severity). No maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval. Per P-1-9, first-time contributors with only automated reviews and no human reviewer engagement are unlikely to merge. The unresolved architectural concern from Greptile is a blocker.

Terminal non-merge signal: Author (0xRaini) explicitly closed the PR with comment 'Closing — focusing on higher-impact, smaller PRs.' This is a direct author closure statement per P-1-2 pattern. Even though sebslight (MEMBER) provided constructive review feedback and the author made fixes, the author's own closure decision overrides all positive signals. The author explicitly chose not to merge despite maintainer feedback.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with only automated Greptile review comment (CONTRIBUTOR role, not human reviewer). Greptile flagged 'Inconsistent API key masking' concern (architectural inconsistency). No maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval. Per P-1-9 and P-7-2, first-time contributors with only automated reviews and no maintainer engagement are unlikely to merge. The unresolved masking inconsistency is a blocker.

Terminal positive merge signal: Member (thewilloftheshadow) comment contains explicit merge receipt language 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with related tests and land/merge commit hashes provided. Per P-2-2, a commit-hash-backed merge receipt from a member is a terminal positive signal overriding all other factors. Author has 25% merge rate (1/4 prior PRs), narrow scope (2 files), and Discord gateway fix is focused. The merge receipt is authoritative.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with 16 files changed (M-L scope) and multiple plugin additions. Only automated Greptile review with flagged concerns ('Incorrect highlight counts' in Kindle tool). Author comment indicates intent to split into separate PRs, suggesting self-awareness of scope but also signaling the current PR is superseded by planned smaller PRs. No maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval. Per P-1-9, first-time contributors with only automated reviews and multi-file scope without maintainer engagement are unlikely to merge.

Author (0xRaini) has 47 prior PRs with 10.6% merge rate (established contributor, not low-merge-rate despite below-average rate). Narrow scope (2 files, XS), focused agent fix. Striking (CONTRIBUTOR with domain authority) commented approvingly: 'This looks right: limitHistoryTurns can definitely orphan tool_result blocks' and offered conditional approval pending CI green. Author proactively closed duplicate PR #13903, demonstrating good citizenship. Author's comment 'CI should be green shortly' indicates confidence. The fix is technically sound per Striking's review. While 0xRaini's merge rate is modest, the combination of focused scope, domain reviewer endorsement, and duplicate management signals merge intent.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XL-sized PR (8 files) and vague title 'Structured log extraction' with no description provided. Only automated Greptile review with 4 comments (typical Greptile surface-level feedback). No maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval. Per P-1-6, new feature addition from first-time contributor without tests, maintainer engagement, or approval is unlikely to merge. Per P-1-5, PR with vague/placeholder title and zero human reviews is unreliable merge candidate. The XL size combined with zero human engagement and first-time contributor status is a strong non-merge signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XS scope (4 files). Author's follow-up comment indicates this is a resubmission/superseded by a new PR series (#18104 onwards). The comment 'Resubmitted as fresh PR with full community context' is a strong signal the original PR is being abandoned in favor of a coordinated multi-part series. No maintainer label, no approval, no human reviewer engagement. CLAWDINATOR bot comment fragment suggests triage review but text is truncated. Pattern P-1-2 applies: author self-identifies this PR as superseded by successor PRs in the same tracking issue.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS scope (2 files) in agents category. Only automated review (greptile) comment, no human reviewer engagement, no approval, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Pattern P-1-10 applies: first-time contributor with only automated reviews and no human reviewer engagement is unlikely to merge. Narrow scope (2 files) and agents category are minor positive signals but insufficient without human engagement or maintainer label.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XS scope (3 files). CLAWDINATOR bot comment explicitly closes PR in favor of duplicate #3368: 'closing in favor of that PR'. Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) comment flagged this as duplicate of #3368. Author's self-advocacy response does not overcome the explicit bot closure comment. Pattern P-5-4 (member closure as duplicate) and Pattern P-1-2 (supersession by another PR) both apply. Terminal non-merge signal despite automated review engagement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with S scope (7 files) in agents/docker categories. MEMBER comment (tyler6204) explicitly states 'Superseded by https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/10776' with merge commit hash. Pattern P-2-1 applies: maintainer/member comment stating PR is 'Fixed in #NNNN' or superseded is a terminal non-merge signal, overriding all other positive indicators including automated review engagement, tests, and narrow scope. This is a definitive closure signal.

Experienced contributor (sebslight, 7 prior PRs, 100% merge rate) with docs-only XS scope (5 files) and maintainer label. Maintainer label alone carries 90.7% merge rate per dataset. High-confidence author history (7/7 merged) reinforces strong merge signal. No CI failures visible, focused doc refactoring scope. Docs category is in top 3 categories. Pattern P-5-6 exception does not apply: author has strong track record (7 prior PRs, not 1), and maintainer label is present which overrides the requirement for human reviewer engagement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XL scope (10 files, labeled 'size: XL') in agents/docs categories. Only automated review (greptile) comment with technical concern about schema validation. No human reviewer approval, no maintainer comment, no maintainer label. Pattern P-1-4 applies: large-scope PRs (10 files = XL) from first-time contributors without maintainer labels and lacking human reviewer approval are unlikely to merge. The greptile comment identifies a potential schema issue (MemoryRecallSchema optionality) without resolution, adding negative signal. No evidence of author response or fix.

Experienced contributor (quotentiroler, 18 prior PRs, 83.3% merge rate) with maintainer label and docs-focused XS scope (4 files). Maintainer label carries 90.7% merge rate in dataset. Author's strong prior merge rate (15/18 = 83.3%) and docs category (top 3) reinforce merge likelihood. Automated review engagement (greptile) is present. No failing CI, focused scope on docs infrastructure improvements. High confidence despite zero human reviewer comments, as maintainer label and author experience override that signal per dataset patterns.

Experienced contributor (Takhoffman, 13 prior PRs, 92.3% merge rate) with maintainer label and focused S scope (6 files) in agents/whatsapp-web categories. Maintainer label is a very strong 90.7% merge rate signal. Author's exceptional prior merge rate (12/13 = 92.3%) is among the highest in dataset. Feature scope (heartbeat/cron injection) is well-scoped. Automated review engagement (greptile). No CI failures or concerns visible. Maintainer label + high author merge rate + narrow scope = high confidence merge prediction.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS scope (2 files) in agents category. Author explicitly closes PR with comment: 'Closing as this was a test/learning PR. The fix has been validated and all CI checks pass. Can be reopened if needed.' Pattern P-1-2 applies: author self-identifies PR as closed/not ready for merge ('test/learning PR'). Despite rmdmattingly (NONE role) offering format patch and acknowledging fix validity, author's explicit closure statement is terminal. No maintainer label, no human approval, first-time contributor status. Author's own statement that this is a learning exercise and closure intent overrides narrow scope and passing CI.

Low-merge-rate contributor (BinHPdev, 3 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate = 0/3) with XS scope (2 files) in slack channel. Author explicitly closes PR with detailed comment explaining backward-compatibility concerns and migration requirements: 'Closing: removing `.toLowerCase()` would break existing tests... A proper fix requires a migration strategy'. Pattern P-1-2 applies: author self-identifies issue with current approach and closes PR pending better design. Despite XS scope and narrow focus, author's explicit closure statement citing technical blockers (test breakage, migration needed) is terminal. 0% merge rate (0/3) on prior PRs adds signal author changes don't typically merge. No maintainer label, no approval.

Member sebslight comment appears truncated but reads '. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' This pattern matches P-6-3: explicit duplicate closure language from a member. The PR has zero human reviewer engagement (only greptile automated review), first-time contributor status, and no maintainer label. The member comment signals closure as duplicate despite the procedural courtesy clause. Terminal non-merge signal.

Title 'Experiment 3' is a placeholder with no substantive description. First-time contributor, zero human reviewer comments (only greptile automated bot), no maintainer engagement, no maintainer label, no tests. This matches P-5-5: vague/placeholder title combined with zero review activity signals unreliable merge candidate. Single file change to README suggests experimental or placeholder change. Terminal non-merge signal due to lack of human engagement and placeholder nature.

Author explicitly states multiple times: 'Duplicate PR: Already solved by #9209' and 'Closing this PR in favor of #9209'. This is a terminal non-merge signal per P-1-2 and P-3-1: author self-declaration of supersession by another PR number. The author confirms PR #9209 is already approved and implements the identical fix. Even though the fix itself is technically correct and addresses the same issue, the author's own statement that the work landed elsewhere (PR #9209) overrides all other considerations. Author also has 0% merge rate across 16 prior PRs, compounding the signal.

Multiple terminal non-merge signals: (1) HenryLoenwind and greptile-apps explicitly label this as 'spam/malicious' and 'marketing materials disguised as skill integrations'. (2) The PR adds affiliate commission programs benefiting the submitter, which violates project principles. (3) No human reviewer approval, no maintainer engagement, first-time contributor. (4) While the author responds acknowledging the issue and proposing to resubmit one-at-a-time, this does not save the current PR — it remains rejected content. The spam/malicious label combined with contributor agreement that it requires restructuring is a terminal non-merge signal.

XL-sized PR (18 files) from first-time contributor author with 0% merge rate across 11 prior PRs. No human reviewer engagement (only automated reviews from greptile and chatgpt-codex-connector). No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, no approval. This matches P-2-3: XL-sized PRs from first-time contributors without maintainer labels/approval/engagement are unlikely to merge. The absence of any human review or approval despite the substantial scope (18 files across extensions and core transcription) combined with the author's poor merge history signals closure.

First-time contributor (1 prior PR, 0% merge rate) with extensive self-advocacy comments (5 total) but zero human reviewer approvals. The PR shows iterative refinement responding to greptile bot reviews and adding test coverage to prevent drift, demonstrating technical competence. However, this matches P-1-10 and P-2-4: first-time contributors with high self-advocacy but no human reviewer approval have low merge probability. The multiple self-pings to greptile-apps for re-review without any human reviewer engagement (all 9 reviews are from greptile or the author themselves) is a compensatory signal, not a terminal positive signal. No maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Likely closed without merge.

Author rodrigouroz has 50% merge rate across 6 prior PRs (3 merged), which is above baseline. PR has trusted-contributor label (very strong signal: ~97% merge rate historically), size S, and changes to core areas (agents, gateway, cron normalization). Only one comment from Takhoffman (CONTRIBUTOR, non-binding) and greptile review. No explicit approval or maintainer comment, but the trusted-contributor label is a dominant positive signal per the feature importance. The absence of negative signals (no draft, no duplicate closure, no 0% merge rate) combined with the trusted-contributor label and reasonable scope predicts merge despite lack of explicit human approval.

Member thewilloftheshadow provides explicit closure direction: 'This should be a pi thing including a separate fireworks provider in pi', signaling the feature scope is being redirected to a different approach/location (Pi subsystem). The author agrees and states 'i am fine with the closure and will look at implementing in Pi', indicating acceptance of the closure. While this is not an explicit 'duplicate of #NNNN' statement, it represents member-directed scope rejection with author agreement. The PR will not be merged in its current form — the feature will be resubmitted under the Pi framework. Terminal non-merge signal for this specific PR.

Contributor steipete provides critical post-merge feedback: 'accidentally merged this but it's problematic' with detailed bug report (process.cwd() usage instead of workspace-specific paths in post-compaction context). This matches P-5-4 (batch accidental merge revert) and P-5-3 (revert signal). Although the author acknowledges the bugs and commits to fixes via separate PR #18914, this PR itself was merged accidentally and the maintainer/contributor community recognizes it as problematic. The PR had already been merged but is now effectively reverted/superseded by the acknowledged bugs and follow-up PR #18914. The 0% merge rate (0 of 6 prior PRs) combined with acknowledged critical bugs in this PR's changes signal it will not remain merged.

Author xinhuagu explicitly states 'Closing to restructure — will resubmit with cleaner approach.' This is a clear closure signal from the PR author. While the author has a reasonable merge rate (33.3% across 12 prior PRs) and a trusted-contributor label (positive signals), the author's own decision to close the PR overrides these factors. The PR will not be merged in its current form. The CI failure explanation (pre-existing tsgo error unrelated to the PR) is noted but does not prevent the author's closure decision. Terminal non-merge signal due to author-initiated closure.

duplicates.evidence: Both PRs target identical file (src/agents/bash-tools.exec.ts) and address related child process/stdio stream lifecycle issues in the agents subsystem. PR #9082 ('FD leak in bash-tools by properly destroying child process streams') and PR #9087 ('close child stdio streams on session exit') appear to target the same underlying problem. PR #9087 is closed with explicit supersession comment 'Closed by #14257 — replaced with a unified process supervisor', suggesting the work was consolidated. PR #9082 is closed as duplicate per sebslight member comment. Both PRs modify the same file and address overlapping concerns, suggesting they may have been competing approaches to the same issue.

matthewpapa07 explicitly identifies three competing PRs attempting to fix the same cron job skipping issue: PR #9573 (lihn-ai-engineer), PR #9589 (rodrigouroz), and PR #9393 (referenced as 'different fix'). matthewpapa07's comment 'all 3 fixes are pretty different. Gotta love vibe coding lol' indicates independent attempts at the same problem. PR #9573 is explicitly pointed to from PR #9589 comments, and both target src/cron/service/store.ts and timer/job skipping behavior. PR #9393 is referenced in PR #9573 comment as an alternative. These are clear duplicates attempting to address the same underlying cron reliability issue.

Weak potential duplicate connection: PR #10406 is explicitly closed as duplicate of an unnamed canonical PR ('Closing as duplicate/, which is the canonical PR...'). The reference is truncated. PR #16082 involves multiple unrelated changes including docker-setup and extensions. Without the explicit canonical PR number for #10406, cannot confirm #16082 is the target, but both touch docker components. Low confidence due to incomplete information.

Both PRs fix the same WhatsApp filename bug (hardcoded 'file' → use actual filename). PR #6372 flagged as duplicate of #7458 by Glucksberg. PR #6505 addresses the same underlying issue #10862 with nearly identical file changes (src/web/outbound.ts, src/web/active-listener.ts, src/web/inbound/send-api.ts all touched in both). Overlapping scope and identical root cause suggest one should be closed in favor of the other. Both have member triage comments with duplicate-closure language.

Both PRs address Docker ARM64 image tagging issues in .github/workflows/docker-release.yml. PR #4577 created 2026-01-30T10:33:16Z, PR #4679 created 2026-01-30T14:03:39Z (3.5 hours later). PR #4679 title explicitly references 'fix(session): correct ARM64 Docker image tagging (issue #4566)' suggesting it is the intended replacement. Both closed/not merged per member triage logic. Likely PR #4679 supersedes PR #4577.

PR #10535 explicitly closed by author w0s1nsk1 with comment 'Closing per request; reopening as a fresh PR without legacy asteriskAri.format.' PR #10581 is the fresh reopening by same author w0s1nsk1, same 9 files (voice-call asterisk-ari provider), same component area. #10535 → #10581 is direct supersession. #10581 is the active continuation; #10535 is the closed predecessor.

Both PRs authored by w0s1nsk1 within 25 minutes of each other (2026-02-09 09:10 and 09:35). Both touch identical file sets in voice-call extension (16-18 files overlap: extensions/voice-call/, media-understanding/transcribe.ts, extensionAPI.ts). #12485 is 'ARI core STT + improved VAD' and #12494 is 'Asterisk ARI provider + core STT'. These appear to be successive iterations or alternative approaches to the same voice-call feature. #12494 is slightly larger (18 vs 16 files) and includes test files (ari-client.test.ts, ari-media.test.ts) that may be refinements. Likely #12494 supersedes #12485 as the more complete version, though neither comment explicitly states this relationship.

Weak similarity: both relate to safety/security scanning (media understanding type-checking, comprehensive security audit). However, #7268 is XS-sized media fix while #9806 is L-sized security scanner — different scope and areas. No explicit comment linking them. Low confidence; unlikely true duplicates but share security/safety domain.

Both PRs from author Clawborn, both closed by author with identical phrasing ('overlaps with #8078'), both targeting config security (proto-pollution), both XS-sized, both address overlapping concerns in merge/deepMerge logic. Strong likelihood these are related attempts by same author addressing same underlying issue class.

Both PRs superseded by maintainer comment from tyler6204 (MEMBER). Both small-to-medium scope. Both closed with supersession language indicating work absorbed into other PRs. Both represent abandoned improvements in favor of other concurrent work.

Author 0xRaini explicitly closed #13903 as duplicate in PR #13906 comments with statement 'Closed #13903 as duplicate — keeping this one.' Striking's review in #13906 also noted: 'PR #13906 and #13903 appear to address the same issue with near-identical diffs—probably only one should land.' Terminal duplicate relationship confirmed by author decision to keep #13906 and close #13903.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly flags PR #8170 as duplicate of PR #3368: 'This appears to duplicate PR #3368, which implements the same fix.' CLAWDINATOR bot confirms closure in favor of #3368: 'closing in favor of that PR.' Author acknowledges the duplicate status but argues for technical differentiation (sync with latest web-ui changes, edge case handling). However, maintainer bot closure takes precedence. Pattern P-5-1 (member duplicate closure) and P-5-4 (explicit duplicate comment) both indicate #8170 is a superseded duplicate of #3368.

MEMBER comment (tyler6204) on PR #8222 explicitly states: 'Superseded by https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/10776 (merge commit: ).' This is a direct supersession statement indicating PR #10776 contains the equivalent or expanded fix. The merge commit reference confirms #10776 was merged. Pattern P-2-1 applies: maintainer statement of supersession is a terminal signal. #8222 is not a true duplicate (distinct authors, different scope) but is superseded by the more comprehensive #10776.

PR #9230 author (vishaltandale00) explicitly identifies PR #9209 as a duplicate, stating 'This PR fixes issue #9203 but PR #9209 already implements the same fix for issue #9204 (which appears to be the same issue)'. Author confirms PR #9209 is already APPROVED (2/2 votes) and both PRs modify the identical file (src/tui/tui-event-handlers.ts) with identical fixes. Author closes in favor of #9209. Terminal duplicate identification.
